entry.title: OAuth2.0 Authentication Error When Setting Up Comm. Arrangement for an External API in Public Cloud
entry.content:
The objective is to consume the IRBM API (used for Malaysian e-invoicing) directly from S/4 Public Cloud.
And for that, we created a Communication Arrangement to establish the connection but we’re getting an authentication error when checking the connection:

Below are the setups for Communication Arrangement & System. For the Communication System, we specified the URL under Hostname and set Port as “443” for HTTPS call.

Under the OAuth 2.0 Settings, the base url with “/connect/token” are specified in order to get the token. 

NOTE: I have tried to remove the Authorization Endpoint and make it empty but it’s still throwing the same issue:

Also, an outbound user with OAuth2.0 authentication is set up to call the IRBM API from S/4 Public Cloud:

Here’s the setup for the Communication Arrangement where we specified an additional scope “Invoicing API”.

We’ve tested this API in Postman, and it works fine as token can be retrieved successfully.

1 point to note, we also included the parameter grant_type during Postman testing but from my understanding this will be automatically handled by standard. But please let me know if this not the case or there’s a missing setup in the Communication System or Arrangement.

entry.title: Material & Quality Management in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Table of Contents

  1. Introduction
    • 1.1. Purpose of This Guide
    • 1.2. Target Audience
    • 1.3. The End-to-End Business Flow
    • 1.4. Navigating SAP S/4HANA: Fiori Launchpad vs. SAP GUI
  2. Chapter 1: The Foundation - Master Data Management
    • 2.2.1. Key Concepts
    • 2.2.2. How-To: Create a New Supplier
    • 2.2.3. How-To: Modify an Existing Supplier
    • 2.3.1. Key Concepts: Material Types, Views, and Organizational Levels
    • 2.3.2. How-To: Create the Quality Management View for a Material
    • 2.3.3. Deep Dive: Understanding the QM View Fields
    • 2.4.1. Key Concepts
    • 2.4.2. How-To: Create a Batch Master Record
    • 2.4.3. How-To: Modify a Batch Master Record
    • 2.5.1. Key Concepts
    • 2.5.2. Process Overview
    • 2.1. Business Case: Setting Up a New Supplier and Material
    • 2.2. Managing Suppliers (Vendors)
    • 2.3. Managing Product (Material) Masters
    • 2.4. Batch Management Essentials
    • 2.5. Serial Number Management Essentials
    • 2.6. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  3. Chapter 2: Procurement with Integrated Quality Management
    • 3.3.1. Initial Screen
    • 3.3.2. Overview Screen & Quantity Check
    • 3.3.3. Handling Batch-Managed Materials (Batch Split)
    • 3.3.4. Saving the Inbound Delivery
    • 3.1. Business Case: Procuring a Quality-Managed Material
    • 3.2. Process Overview
    • 3.3. How-To: Create an Inbound Delivery
    • 3.4. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  4. Chapter 3: The Quality Inspection Cycle
    • 4.3.1. Accessing the Application
    • 4.3.2. Initial Selection
    • 4.3.3. Results Recording Screen
    • 4.1. Business Case: Inspecting Incoming Goods
    • 4.2. Process Overview
    • 4.3. How-To: Record Inspection Results
    • 4.4. How-To: Make a Usage Decision (Process Completion)
    • 4.5. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  5. Chapter 4: Product Lifecycle - Obsoleting and Archiving
    • 5.3.1. Identifying Candidates for Deletion
    • 5.3.2. Setting the Deletion Flag Immediately
    • 5.3.3. Understanding Deletion at Different Organizational Levels
    • 5.1. Business Case: Phasing Out an Obsolete Material
    • 5.2. Key Concepts: Deletion Flag vs. Archiving
    • 5.3. How-To: Mark a Material for Deletion
    • 5.4. How-To: Schedule the Deletion Flag for a Future Date
    • 5.5. How-To: Cancel a Deletion Flag
    • 5.6. The Archiving Process: An Overview for Key Users
    • 5.7. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  6. Chapter 5: Comprehensive Business Case Test Plan
    • 6.1. Introduction to the Test Plan
    • 6.2. Scenario 1: Full Procure-to-Quality-Approval Cycle
    • 6.3. Scenario 2: Material Obsolescence and Data Maintenance

 

  • 1. Introduction
  • 1.1. Purpose of This blog

 We will walk through the entire lifecycle of a product—from setting up the necessary master data, procuring it with quality checks, inspecting it, and finally, managing its obsolescence.

  • 1.2. Target Audience

This guide is tailored for a diverse audience:

  • End Users: Provides clear, step-by-step instructions with screenshots to perform daily tasks confidently.
  • Key Users: Offers deeper insights into the process flow, integration points, and advanced functionalities to support business operations.
  • Consultants & Dummies: Includes conceptual explanations and configuration notes (SPRO/CBC paths) to understand the "why" behind the "how" and to facilitate system setup and troubleshooting.
  • 1.3. The End-to-End Business Flow

We will follow a logical business narrative that connects all the individual tasks into one seamless story:

Setup -> Execute -> Inspect -> Retire

  1. Setup (Chapter 1): We begin by laying the groundwork. We'll create a Supplier from whom we will procure goods. Then, we will define a Product (Material) in the system, paying special attention to the Quality Management parameters that dictate how it will be inspected. We'll also cover the basics of Batch and Serial Number management.
  2. Execute (Chapter 2): With our master data in place, we will execute a procurement process. This chapter focuses on creating an Inbound Delivery, which is the notification that our ordered goods are on their way.
  3. Inspect (Chapter 3): Once the goods arrive, the quality process kicks in. We will learn how to find the inspection task, record the results of our quality checks, and make a Usage Decision to either accept the materials into our stock or reject them.
  4. Retire (Chapter 4): Products don't last forever. When a material becomes obsolete, we need a clean process to phase it out. We will cover how to mark materials for deletion to prevent their future use and discuss the final step of archiving.
  • 1.4. Navigating SAP S/4HANA: Fiori Launchpad vs. SAP GUI

SAP S/4HANA offers two primary user interfaces. This guide will prioritize the modern, web-based SAP Fiori Launchpad but will also provide the classic SAP GUI transaction codes for reference.

  • SAP Fiori: A user-friendly, role-based interface with "Apps" for specific tasks. We will reference Fiori Apps wherever a modern equivalent exists.
  • SAP GUI (Graphical User Interface): The classic interface. We will provide transaction codes (T-codes) like MM06, MSC2N, etc., which can be used directly in the SAP GUI or in the Fiori Launchpad's search bar.

 

  • Chapter 1: The Foundation - Master Data Management
  • 2.1. Business Case: Setting Up a New Supplier and Material

Before any transaction can occur, we must first define the "who" and the "what." In this chapter, we will onboard a new supplier, "Bildor Transport Services LTD," and create a new raw material, "CAPSULE VP7 20 CS VAG," that requires quality inspection upon receipt. This foundational data will drive all subsequent processes in our guide.

  • 2.2. Managing Suppliers (Vendors)

A supplier master record contains all the necessary information about a business partner from whom we procure goods or services. This includes general data (name, address), company code data (accounting information), and purchasing data (payment terms, currency).

  • 2.2.1. Key Concepts
  • Business Partner (BP): In S/4HANA, suppliers are created as a Business Partner with a specific role (e.g., Supplier). This is a change from the old ERP model.
  • Purchasing Organization: The organizational unit responsible for negotiating purchasing conditions with suppliers. A supplier must be extended to a purchasing organization to be used in procurement.
  • Company Code: The organizational unit for which a complete set of financial accounts is maintained. Extending a supplier to a company code allows for financial postings.
  • 2.2.2. How-To: Create a New Supplier

We will create the supplier "Bildor transport services LTD."

  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data
  • SAP GUI T-code: BP

Step 1: Launch the App and Choose Creation Mode Open the "Manage Business Partner Master Data" app and click "Create -> Organization".

Step 2: Enter General Data In the "General Data" section, fill in the essential information for the supplier.

  • BP Role: Choose "Supplier".
  • Name: Bildor transport services LTD
  • Address: 11 Garamonde Drive, Milton Keynes, GB

Step 3: Extend to Company Code Navigate to the "Company Code" tab and click "Create".

  • Company Code: Enter your company code (e.g., 0500).
  • Recon. Account: Select the appropriate reconciliation account for supplier payables. Click Apply.

Step 4: Extend to Purchasing Organization Navigate to the "Purchasing" tab and click "Create".

  • Purchasing Organization: Enter your purchasing organization (e.g., VAL5).
  • Order Currency: EUR
  • Payment Terms: Select the relevant payment terms. Click Apply.

Step 5: Save the Supplier Click the Save button at the bottom of the screen. The system will confirm the creation and assign a Business Partner number (e.g., 11895).

  • 2.2.3. How-To: Modify an Existing Supplier

Let's say our supplier "DECOPART" has officially changed its name to "DECOPART LTD."

  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data
  • SAP GUI T-code: BP

Step 1: Find the Supplier Open the "Manage Business Partner Master Data" app. Use the search fields to find the supplier by name ("DECOPART") or number.

Step 2: Enter Edit Mode Once you have opened the supplier's record, click the Edit button.

Step 3: Change the Name In the "General Data" section, modify the Name field from DECOPART to DECOPART LTD.

Step 4: Save the Changes Click the Save button. The changes are now active.

 

  • 2.3. Managing Product (Material) Masters

The product master is the central source of information for a material. It is used across all departments, from purchasing and production to sales and accounting.

  • 2.3.1. Key Concepts: Material Types, Views, and Organizational Levels
  • Material Type: A grouping of materials with the same basic attributes. For example:
    • ROH (Raw Materials): Purchased externally, used in production.
    • HALB (Semi-finished Goods): Produced in-house, used to make finished goods.
    • FERT (Finished Goods): Produced in-house, sold to customers.
    • HAWA (Trading Goods): Purchased and resold without transformation.
  • Views: The material master is organized into different screens called "views," each corresponding to a specific business function (e.g., Purchasing, MRP, Sales, Quality Management).
  • Organizational Levels: Data can be maintained at different levels.
    • Client: General data (e.g., description, unit of measure) is valid for the entire organization.
    • Plant (Division): Data specific to a facility (e.g., QM, planning data) is maintained at the plant level.
  • 2.3.2. How-To: Create the Quality Management View for a Material

We will now add quality management data to an existing raw material.

  • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data
  • SAP GUI T-code: MM01 (Create) / MM02 (Change)

Note: Even if a material already exists, you use the "Create" (MM01) logic to add a new view (like QM) that has never been created before. If the view already exists and you want to change it, you use "Change" (MM02).

Step 1: Access the Transaction Open the "Manage Product Master Data" app or enter MM01 in the GUI.

  • Material: Enter the material number, e.g., 922173.
  • Industry Sector: P (Pharmacy)
  • Material Type: ROH (Raw material)

Press Enter.

Step 2: Select the View A "Select View(s)" pop-up will appear. Check the box for Quality Management and click Continue.

Step 3: Specify Organizational Levels The system will ask for the plant where the view should be created.

  • Plant: Enter the plant code, e.g., 0110. Click Continue.

Step 4: Maintain QM View Data The "Quality Management" view will now be displayed. Fill in the required fields based on your business rules. A detailed explanation of these fields is in the next section.

  • QM in Procurement: Check this box to activate quality control for procurement.
  • QM Control Key: Select Z004 (requires authorization, technical delivery conditions, certificate, and samples).
  • Technical Delivery Condit.: Check this box.

Step 5: Link Technical Delivery Conditions (CTL/Q-Spec) Because we are using a QM Control Key that requires it, we must link a document. After entering the QM data and pressing Enter, a screen to link documents will appear.

  • Document Type: Q02
  • Document: Search for and select the appropriate document, e.g., CTL03 (Samples + Quality Certificate).

Step 6: Save the Record Click the Save icon. The system will confirm that the material has been created or extended.

 

  • 2.3.3. Deep Dive: Understanding the QM View Fields

Let's explore the key fields on the Quality Management view.

  • Donn. générales (General Data)
    • Inspection setup: This button is the most important part of the QM view. Here you define the inspection types (e.g., 01 for Goods Receipt Inspection from a Purchase Order) that will be active for this material. Activating an inspection type is what tells the system to automatically create an inspection lot during a business process.
    • QM authorization: An additional authorization check for this material.
    • Plant-sp. matl status (Statut art. par div.): A status that can block the material from being used in certain processes (e.g., procurement, production) at this specific plant.
  • Données réappros (Procurement Data)
    • Whether a technical delivery document is required.
    • Whether a quality certificate is expected from the supplier.
    • Whether the goods receipt should be blocked until inspection is complete.
    • Whether a specific quality agreement is in place.
    • Example Keys:
      • 0001: Standard, no special requirements.
      • Z002: Requires a Quality Certificate.
      • Z004: Requires a Certificate and Samples.
    • QM in Procurement Active (QM dans Réappro.): This is the master switch. Activating this checkbox enables quality management functionalities for the procurement of this material at this plant.
    • QM Control Key (Clé de commande QM): A powerful key that defines various control parameters for procurement, such as:
    • Certificate Type: If a certificate is required, this field specifies the exact type.
    • Condit.techn.livr (Technical Delivery Conditions): This checkbox indicates that a document (like a specification drawing or a quality agreement) is linked to the material for procurement purposes.

 

  • 2.4. Batch Management Essentials

Batch management is used to track groups of materials with unique characteristics, often based on a production run. It's crucial for industries like pharmaceuticals, food, and chemicals for traceability and handling variations.

  • 2.4.1. Key Concepts
  • Batch: A quantity of material produced during a single production run or received in a single shipment, which is assumed to have uniform characteristics. Each batch is given a unique number.
  • Batch Master Record: Contains details about a specific batch, such as its creation date, expiration date, and classification (e.g., potency, color).
  • 2.4.2. How-To: Create a Batch Master Record

While batches are often created automatically during goods receipt or production reporting, you can also create them manually.

  • Fiori App: Manage Batches
  • SAP GUI T-code: MSC1N

Step 1: Enter Initial Information Launch the app or transaction.

  • Material: Enter the material number that is batch-managed, e.g., 10039781.
  • Batch: If using internal number assignment, leave this blank. If external, enter the batch number.
  • Plant: Enter the plant, e.g., 0120. Press Enter.

Step 2: Enter Batch Details On the "Basic data 1" tab, enter the key information.

  • Production Date (Date fabricat.): Enter the date the batch was produced.
  • Shelf Life Expiration Date (Date pérempt./DLC): The system may calculate this automatically based on the material master settings, or you can enter it manually.
  • Status: The initial status is usually "Unrestricted." It can be changed to "Restricted" if there is a quality issue.

Step 3: Save the Batch Click the Save icon. The system will confirm the creation in the status bar with the message "Batch XXXXX for material YYYYY was created."

  • 2.4.3. How-To: Modify a Batch Master Record

You can change batch information, such as updating the expiration date or changing its status.

  • Fiori App: Manage Batches
  • SAP GUI T-code: MSC2N

Step 1: Select the Batch Launch the app or transaction.

  • Material: 10034521
  • Batch: V400112754
  • Plant: Enter the relevant plant. Press Enter.

Step 2: Make Modifications The batch master data is displayed across several tabs ("Basic data 1", "Basic data 2", "Classification"). You can, for example:

  • Change the Shelf Life Expiration Date.
  • Change the Status from "Unrestricted" to "Restricted".
  • Add a text description on the "Basic data 2" tab.

Step 3: Save the Changes Click the Save icon. The system confirms that the batch has been modified.

 

  • 2.5. Serial Number Management Essentials

Serial numbers are used to identify and track individual items (a single piece) of a material. This provides the highest level of traceability, essential for high-value items, products requiring individual service history (like equipment), or for warranty management.

  • 2.5.1. Key Concepts
  • Serial Number Profile: A key assigned to the material master that defines how and when serial numbers are to be assigned for different business transactions (e.g., goods receipt, delivery to customer).
  • Equipment Master Record: From a technical standpoint in SAP, a serial number is an "incomplete" equipment master record. You can later add more data to it (like maintenance plans or warranty information) to turn it into a "complete" piece of equipment managed by the Plant Maintenance (PM) or Customer Service (CS) modules.
  • 2.5.2. Process Overview

The general flow for using serial numbers is as follows:

  1. Configuration: Create a Serial Number Profile in customizing to define the serialization procedures.
  2. Material Master: Assign the created Serial Number Profile to the material master record (in the "Plant data / stor. 2" or "Sales: General/Plant" view).
  3. Transaction Execution: During a business process (like the goods receipt in our upcoming chapter), the system will prompt you to enter a serial number for each individual unit of the material.
    • You can assign numbers manually.
    • The system can assign numbers automatically from a pre-defined range.
  4. Tracking: The system now has a record of each unique, serialized item, which can be tracked throughout its entire lifecycle in the warehouse and beyond.
  • 2.6. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  • Business Partner (Supplier):
    • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> SAP Business Partner -> Business Partner -> Basic Settings -> Business Partner Roles -> Define BP Roles. Here you define and configure the roles like "Supplier".
    • SPRO Path: Cross-Application Components -> Master Data Synchronization -> Customer/Vendor Integration -> Business Partner Settings -> Settings for Vendor Integration -> Field Assignment for Vendor Integration -> Assign Keys -> Define Number Assignment for Direction BP to Vendor. This is where you configure the number range mapping between the BP and the classic vendor number.
  • Material Master:
    • SPRO Path: Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Basic Settings -> Material Types -> Define Attributes of Material Types. Here you define which views (e.g., Quality Management) are allowed for each material type (e.g., ROH).
  • Quality Management:
    • SPRO Path: Quality Management -> QM in Logistics -> QM in Procurement -> Define Control Keys. This is where you create and maintain the QM Control Keys (0001, Z002, etc.).
  • Batch Management:
    • SPRO Path: Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Specify Batch Level and Activate Status Management. Here you define if batch uniqueness is at the material, plant, or client level.
  • Serial Number Management:
    • SPRO Path: Plant Maintenance and Customer Service -> Master Data in Plant Maintenance and Customer Service -> Technical Objects -> Serial Number Management -> Define Serial Number Profiles. This is where you create the serial number profiles and define the procedures for each business transaction (e.g., MMSL for goods movements).

 

  • Chapter 2: Procurement with Integrated Quality Management
  • 3.1. Business Case: Procuring a Quality-Managed Material

Now that our master data is set up, it's time to put it into action. We have placed a purchase order with our supplier, "TEWI-PLEX EUROPE NV," for 520,000 units of the batch-managed material 290050. The supplier has shipped the goods and provided an external delivery note number 78246. Our task is to register this incoming shipment in SAP S/4HANA by creating an inbound delivery.

  • 3.2. Process Overview

The inbound delivery is a crucial document in the receiving process. It serves as a notification of an impending goods receipt and allows for better planning of warehouse activities like putaway. For quality-managed materials, the subsequent goods receipt against this inbound delivery will trigger the creation of an inspection lot, which is the starting point for the quality inspection process.

  • 3.3. How-To: Create an Inbound Delivery

This process registers the expected arrival of goods against a specific purchase order.

  • Fiori App: Create Inbound Deliveries
  • SAP GUI T-code: VL31N
  • 3.3.1. Initial Screen

Step 1: Launch the Application Open the "Create Inbound Deliveries" Fiori app or enter the transaction code VL31N in the SAP GUI.

Step 2: Enter Purchase Order and Delivery Details The initial screen requires you to reference the purchase order you are receiving against.

  • Purchase Order (Commande): Enter the purchase order number, e.g., 4500210533.
  • External Identification (Identification ext.): Enter the supplier's delivery note number, e.g., 78246.
  • Delivery Date (Date livraison): The date of the shipment.

Press Enter to proceed.

 

  • 3.3.2. Overview Screen & Quantity Check

Step 3: Verify the Item Details The system navigates to the overview screen, pulling in all the relevant information from the purchase order, such as the material, quantity, and supplier.

  • By default, the system proposes the full open quantity from the purchase order. In our case, 520,000 MIL (thousands).
  • You can modify the delivery quantity if the supplier has sent a partial shipment.
  • 3.3.3. Handling Batch-Managed Materials (Batch Split)

Since our material 290050 is batch-managed, we must specify the batch number provided by the supplier for this specific shipment.

Step 4: Select the Item and Initiate Batch Split Highlight the line item you wish to process and click the Batch Split (Fractionn. lot) button at the bottom of the screen.

Step 5: Enter Batch Information You are taken to the "Item Detail" screen with a focus on the "Batch Split" tab. Here, you will enter the specific batch details for the quantity being received.

  • Batch (Lot): Enter the supplier's batch number, e.g., 159432. If your system is configured for internal batch numbering upon goods receipt, you might leave this blank and a number will be assigned later. For this scenario, we enter the supplier batch.
  • Delivery quantity (Qté livraison): Enter the quantity corresponding to this specific batch. Here, we enter the full 520,000.

Press Enter.

 

  • 3.3.4. Saving the Inbound Delivery

Step 6: Save the Inbound Delivery Once all quantities and batch information are correctly entered, click the Save icon.

Step 7: Confirmation The system will save the document and return you to the initial screen. You will receive a confirmation message in the status bar at the bottom of the screen: "Inbound delivery 180105904 has been saved."

Result: The inbound delivery is now created. The next step in the physical process is to post the goods receipt with reference to this delivery. Upon goods receipt, the system will automatically create an inspection lot because the material is configured for quality management.

  • 3.4. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  • Delivery Types:
    • SPRO Path: Logistics Execution -> Shipping -> Deliveries -> Define Delivery Types. The standard inbound delivery type is EL. Here you can configure number ranges and other control parameters for the document.
  • Item Categories:
    • SPRO Path: Logistics Execution -> Shipping -> Deliveries -> Define Item Category Determination in Deliveries. This configuration determines which item category (e.g., ELN for standard inbound items) is used in the delivery, which in turn controls aspects like whether picking or putaway is relevant.
  • Batch Determination in Deliveries:
    • SPRO Path: Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Batch Determination and Batch Check -> Strategy Types -> Define Sales and Distribution Strategy Types. Although named for SD, this is where you can configure strategies for how batches are determined or checked during the delivery process.

 

  • Chapter 3: The Quality Inspection Cycle
  • 4.1. Business Case: Inspecting Incoming Goods

Following the goods receipt for our inbound delivery, the system automatically generated an inspection lot 28311 for material 290094. As a quality technician, your task is to access this inspection lot, record the results for the required checks (e.g., certificate review, visual inspection, dimensional check), and ultimately decide whether the material meets our standards.

  • 4.2. Process Overview

The quality inspection process is the practical execution of the rules we defined in the material master's QM view.

  1. Inspection Lot Creation: A goods movement (like a goods receipt) for a QM-activated material triggers the creation of an inspection lot. This is the official request for the quality department to perform an inspection.
  2. Results Recording: The technician performs the required tests (as defined in the inspection plan) and records the findings in SAP. This could be quantitative data (e.g., a measurement) or qualitative data (e.g., pass/fail).
  3. Usage Decision (UD): After all results are recorded, a responsible person (e.g., a quality manager) makes the final "Usage Decision." This decision determines the fate of the material (e.g., accept it to unrestricted stock, block it, or reject it). The UD also triggers stock posting movements in the background.
  • 4.3. How-To: Record Inspection Results

Here we will record the results for our inspection lot.

  • Fiori App: Record Inspection Results
  • SAP GUI T-code: QE01 (obsolete, QA32 is the modern starting point) / QE51N

Note: The modern process starts in the "Manage Inspection Lots" (QA32) app, where you find your lot and then navigate to results recording. The direct T-code QE01 from the source document is less common now. We will follow the flow from the source.

  • 4.3.1. Accessing the Application

Step 1: Launch the Application You can enter QE01 directly in the command field.

  • 4.3.2. Initial Selection

Step 2: Identify the Inspection Lot and Operation On the initial screen, you must specify which inspection lot you want to process.

  • Inspection Lot (Lot de contrôle): Enter the inspection lot number, e.g., 42706 (from the example, though our business case uses 28311).
  • Operation: Enter the operation number from the inspection plan, e.g., 0030. An operation is a single step in the inspection process.

Press Enter or select "Jump -> Results data" from the menu.

 

  • 4.3.3. Results Recording Screen

Step 3: Enter Results for Each Characteristic The system displays the "Characteristic Overview" screen. Each line represents a specific test or check to be performed (an Inspection Characteristic).

  • INFO-N° de gamme (Inspection Plan Info): Informational characteristic.
  • CTRL-Certificat qualité (Quality Certificate Check): A qualitative check. You would enter a result from a catalog, e.g., "OK" or "Not OK".
  • CTRL-Aspect (Visual Aspect Check): Another qualitative check.
  • CTRL-Dimensionnel (Dimensional Check): A quantitative check where you would enter a measured value.

Step 4: Record the Findings Click in the "Result" column for each characteristic and enter the outcome of your inspection.

  • For qualitative characteristics, you might select a code.
  • For quantitative characteristics, you enter a numerical value. The system will automatically evaluate the result (green check for accepted, red X for rejected) based on the tolerances defined in the inspection plan.

Step 5: Save the Results After entering all results, click the Save icon. This saves your findings but does not yet complete the inspection.

  • 4.4. How-To: Make a Usage Decision (Process Completion)

The Usage Decision (UD) is the final step that closes the inspection lot and moves the stock.

  • Fiori App: Manage Usage Decisions
  • SAP GUI T-code: QA32 (then select lot and click UD) or QA11 (direct)

Step 1: Select the Inspection Lot In the "Manage Usage Decisions" app, find your inspection lot (28311).

Step 2: Make the Decision * UD Code: Select a code from the list that represents your decision, for example, A for "Accepted" or R for "Rejected".

  • Inspection Lot Stock: On this tab, you specify how to post the quantity. For an acceptance, you would move the quantity from "Quality inspection" stock to "Unrestricted-use" stock.

Step 3: Save the UD Click Save. The inspection is now complete, the lot is closed, and the stock is available for use.

  • 4.5. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  • Inspection Plan:
    • SPRO Path: Quality Management -> Quality Planning -> Inspection Planning -> General -> .... This is where you configure task list types, profiles, and other settings for creating inspection plans (T-code QP01).
  • Inspection Characteristics:
    • SPRO Path: Quality Management -> Quality Planning -> Basic Data -> Inspection Characteristic, Inspection Method -> .... Here you define master inspection characteristics (T-code QS21) and their control data.
  • Usage Decisions:
    • SPRO Path: Quality Management -> Quality Inspection -> Inspection Lot Completion -> Edit Code Groups and Codes for Usage Decisions. This is where you define the UD codes (e.g., A, R) and their associated follow-up actions, such as triggering automatic stock postings.

 

  • Chapter 4: Product Lifecycle - Obsoleting and Archiving
  • 5.1. Business Case: Phasing Out an Obsolete Material

The material 10716297 is being replaced by a newer version. To prevent users from accidentally ordering or producing this obsolete material, we need to block it from further use. First, we will check if there is any remaining stock. If not, we will set a deletion flag at the plant level to make it unusable within that specific facility.

  • 5.2. Key Concepts: Deletion Flag vs. Archiving

It's crucial to understand the difference between these two related but distinct processes.

  • Deletion Flag (Marking for Deletion): This is a "soft" deletion. You are not removing the material from the database. Instead, you are setting a status on the material master record that prevents its use in future transactions. The system will issue warning or error messages if a user tries to create a purchase order or production order for it. This action is reversible.
  • Archiving: This is the "hard" deletion. An archiving program (SARA) is run periodically by system administrators. It first writes all data for materials that are flagged for deletion to an archive file. Then, it deletes the data from the live SAP database. This is done to save database space and improve system performance. This action is not easily reversible.
  • 5.3. How-To: Mark a Material for Deletion

This is the first and most common step in obsoleting a material.

  • Fiori App: Schedule Deletion of Material
  • SAP GUI T-code: MM06
  • 5.3.1. Identifying Candidates for Deletion

Before flagging a material, you must ensure it is no longer needed. A key prerequisite is that there should be zero stock in the system for the organizational level you are flagging.

Step 1: Check Stock Levels Use a stock reporting app to verify the stock situation.

  • Fiori App: Stock - Single Material or Stock - Multiple Materials
  • SAP GUI T-code: MMBE

Enter your material and plant to confirm that all stock types (unrestricted, quality, blocked) are zero.

Standard Business Process Note: The source document mentions a "Proposals" feature. In a standard system, this translates to a business process:

  1. Run a report like MB5L (List of Stock Values) or a Fiori stock app.
  2. Use the report's filter options to display only materials with zero stock.
  3. Export this list of materials.
  4. Use the exported list as your worklist for marking materials for deletion in the next step.

 

  • 5.3.2. Setting the Deletion Flag Immediately

Step 2: Access the Deletion Transaction Launch the "Schedule Deletion of Material" app or transaction MM06.

  • Material: Enter the material number, e.g., 10716297. Press Enter.

Step 3: Set the Deletion Flag at the Desired Level The "Position deletion flag material" screen appears. You can set the flag at various organizational levels. Check the box corresponding to the level you want to block.

Example 1: Deletion at Client Level To block the material across the entire company, check the box at the very top, next to the material number itself.

  • Effect: This is the highest level. The material is flagged for deletion at the client level and all lower levels (all company codes, all plants, all storage locations).

Example 2: Deletion at Plant Level To block the material only in a specific plant (e.g., 1121) but allow its use in others, first enter the Plant number on the initial screen, then check the box next to the Plant (Division) field on the data screen.

  • Effect: The material is flagged for deletion at this plant and all lower levels within this plant (e.g., all storage locations in plant 1121), but it remains active at the client level and in other plants.

Step 4: Save the Changes Click the Save icon. The deletion flag is now active.

  • 5.4. How-To: Schedule the Deletion Flag for a Future Date

In some cases, you may know a material will be obsolete in the future (e.g., at the end of the quarter) and want to schedule the deletion flag in advance.

  • Fiori App: Not a direct equivalent, typically handled by background jobs.
  • SAP GUI T-code: MM16

The process is similar to MM06, but the transaction is designed to be run in the background. You create a "variant" with the list of materials and the organizational levels to be flagged, and then schedule the program to run on a specific future date.

  • 5.5. How-To: Cancel a Deletion Flag

If a material was marked for deletion by mistake, you can easily reverse the action.

  • Fiori App: Schedule Deletion of Material
  • SAP GUI T-code: MM06

Step 1: Access the Transaction Enter the material and organizational levels in MM06, just as you did when setting the flag.

Step 2: Uncheck the Boxes On the data screen, the checkboxes for the levels where the flag is set will be ticked. Simply uncheck these boxes.

Step 3: Save the Changes Click the Save icon. The deletion flags are removed, and the material is active again at those levels.

  • 5.6. The Archiving Process: An Overview for Key Users

As mentioned, archiving is the final step handled by system administrators.

  1. Prerequisite: A material must have a deletion flag set.
  2. Execution: The administrator uses the Archive Administration transaction (SARA) with the archiving object MM_MATNR.
  3. Jobs: The process involves scheduling several jobs: a "write" job to create the archive file, and a "delete" job to remove the data from the database.
  4. Result: The material data is permanently removed from the operational system.
  • 5.7. Configuration Notes for Consultants
  • Deletion Flag Messages:
    • SPRO Path: Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Basic Settings -> Define Attributes of System Messages. Here you can configure whether the message issued when a user tries to use a flagged material is a Warning (W), an Error (E), or no message. This gives the business flexibility in how strictly the deletion flag is enforced.
  • Archiving Object Configuration:
    • In transaction SARA, selecting the object MM_MATNR and clicking "Customizing" will take you to the specific configuration for material archiving. Here you can set parameters like the size of the archive files and control the technical settings for the write and delete programs.

 

  • Chapter 5: Comprehensive Business Case Test Plan
  • 6.1. Introduction to the Test Plan

This chapter provides a series of structured test scenarios for end users to practice and validate the end-to-end processes covered in this guide. Each scenario includes prerequisites, detailed steps, and expected outcomes.

  • 6.2. Scenario 1: Full Procure-to-Quality-Approval Cycle

Objective: To test the entire process from master data setup through procurement, quality inspection, and stock availability.

Test Case ID

TS-001: Full Lifecycle Test

Description

Create a new raw material and supplier, procure the material, and process it through quality inspection to make it available for use.

Prerequisites

Access to SAP S/4HANA Fiori Launchpad or SAP GUI. Authorization for all transactions mentioned.

 

Step

Action

Detailed Instructions

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

1.0

Master Data: Create Supplier

Use the "Manage Business Partner Master Data" app (BP). - Create a new Organization. - Name: Global Chemicals Inc - Address: 123 Industrial Way, Houston, TX - Extend to your Company Code and Purchasing Org.

Supplier is created successfully with a new BP number.

 

2.0

Master Data: Create Product

Use the "Manage Product Master Data" app (MM01). - Material: Choose a new number, e.g., RM-1001 - Industry: C (Chemical industry) - Material Type: ROH (Raw Material) - Create Basic Data, Purchasing, and General Plant Data views. - Set the Base Unit of Measure to KG.

Material RM-1001 is created.

 

2.1

Master Data: Extend Product for QM

Use the "Manage Product Master Data" app (MM01 or MM02). - Extend material RM-1001 to the Quality Management view for your plant. - Check "QM in Procurement Active". - Set QM Control Key to one that requires a certificate. - Activate Inspection Type 01 in the inspection setup.

The QM view is created and active. The material will now trigger an inspection lot on goods receipt.

 

3.0

Procurement: Create Purchase Order

Use the "Manage Purchase Orders" app (ME21N). - Supplier: Enter the number for Global Chemicals Inc. - Material: RM-1001 - Quantity: 500 KG - Plant: Your plant.

Purchase Order is created successfully.

 

4.0

Logistics: Create Inbound Delivery

Use the "Create Inbound Deliveries" app (VL31N). - Reference the Purchase Order created in the previous step. - External ID: DEL-998877.

Inbound Delivery is created and saved.

 

5.0

Logistics: Post Goods Receipt

Use the "Post Goods Receipt for Inbound Delivery" app (MIGO or VL32N). - Reference your Inbound Delivery. - Post the goods receipt for 500 KG.

A material document is posted. An inspection lot is automatically created. Stock for RM-1001 is now 500 KG in Quality Inspection status.

 

6.0

Quality: Record Results

Use the "Manage Inspection Lots" app (QA32) to find your lot. - Navigate to Results Recording. - Enter results for all characteristics (e.g., mark them as "passed"). - Save the results.

Inspection results are recorded and saved for the lot.

 

7.0

Quality: Make Usage Decision

Use the "Manage Usage Decisions" app (QA32 -> UD). - Select the Usage Decision Code for "Accept". - On the "Inspection lot stock" tab, post the 500 KG from Quality Inspection to Unrestricted-Use.

The inspection lot is closed. The stock for RM-1001 is now 500 KG in Unrestricted-Use status and is available for production or other processes.

 

 

 

  • 6.3. Scenario 2: Material Obsolescence and Data Maintenance

Objective: To test the process for correctly phasing out a material and reversing the action if necessary.

Test Case ID

TS-002: Material Deletion and Reversal

Description

Mark a material with zero stock for deletion at the plant level. Verify the block. Then, cancel the deletion flag to make it active again.

Prerequisites

A material with zero stock in a specific plant. (You can use the material from Scenario 1 after issuing the stock).

 

Step

Action

Detailed Instructions

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

1.0

Preparation: Ensure Zero Stock

Use the "Stock - Single Material" app (MMBE). - Verify that material RM-1001 has a stock of 0 in your plant. If not, perform a goods issue to clear the stock (MIGO, movement type 201).

Stock for RM-1001 is confirmed as 0.

 

2.0

Execution: Mark for Deletion

Use the "Schedule Deletion of Material" app (MM06). - Material: RM-1001 - Press Enter. - On the next screen, enter your Plant and press Enter again. - Check the box next to the Plant field to set the deletion flag at the plant level. - Save.

The deletion flag is set for RM-1001 at the plant level.

 

3.0

Verification: Attempt to Procure

Use the "Create Purchase Order" app (ME21N). - Try to create a new purchase order for material RM-1001 in the plant where it was flagged.

The system should issue a Warning or Error message stating that the material is flagged for deletion, preventing the creation of the PO.

 

4.0

Reversal: Cancel Deletion Flag

Use the "Schedule Deletion of Material" app (MM06). - Enter material RM-1001 and your Plant. - Uncheck the box next to the Plant field. - Save.

The deletion flag is removed.

 

5.0

Verification: Attempt to Procure Again

Use the "Create Purchase Order" app (ME21N). - Try again to create a new purchase order for material RM-1001.

You should now be able to create the purchase order without any warning or error message related to a deletion flag.

 

 

  • Chapter 6: Appendix
  • 6.1. Glossary of Key SAP Terms

This glossary defines common SAP terms encountered throughout this guide and in your daily work, based on the terminology used in the source documents.

  • Archiving (Archivage): The process of removing data from the live database and storing it in an external archive file. This is the final step in deleting a master record and is typically performed to improve system performance. Data is first marked for deletion before it can be archived.
  • Batch (Lot): A quantity of a material that is produced or procured together and is assumed to have uniform characteristics. Batches are used for traceability and managing materials with specific attributes like expiration dates.
  • Business Partner (BP): The central object in S/4HANA for managing master data for all business partners, including customers and suppliers.
  • Client (Mandant): The highest organizational level in SAP. Data defined at the client level is valid for all company codes and organizational units within the system. For example, general material data like the base unit of measure is maintained at the client level.
  • Company (Société): The smallest organizational unit for which a complete, independent set of financial statements can be created (e.g., a balance sheet, P&L statement).
  • Deletion Flag (Témoin de suppression): A status set on a master record (like a material) to indicate that it is obsolete and should be archived. This flag prevents the master record from being used in new transactions but does not physically delete it from the database. The flag can be set at various organizational levels, such as the client or plant level.
  • Inspection Lot (Lot de contrôle): A system-generated request to inspect a specific quantity of material. It serves as the primary object for managing a quality inspection, containing details like the material, quantity, specifications, and a place to record results.
  • Material Type (Type article): A classification that groups materials with similar attributes, such as raw materials (ROH), semi-finished goods (HALB), or finished goods (FERT). The material type controls which views can be created for a material and how it is valuated.
  • Matchcode: A tool used to find records in the system when you don't know the exact number or key. It provides a searchable list of possible entries for a field, often based on criteria like name or description.
  • Plant (Division): An organizational unit within a company that represents a production site, a distribution center, or a branch. Many master data views, such as Quality Management and MRP, are maintained at the plant level.
  • QM Control Key (Clé de commande QM): A configuration key assigned to a material in the QM view that defines specific control parameters for procurement. It can mandate requirements such as supplier authorization, the need for a quality certificate, or technical delivery conditions.
  • Serial Number: A unique number assigned to a single, individual item of a material to differentiate it from all other items of the same material number. It is used for detailed tracking and service management.
  • Technical Delivery Conditions (CTL - Condition technique de livraison): A document (document type Q02 in the example) linked to a material master record to provide specific instructions or requirements to a supplier. This document can be printed on the purchase order and may specify that a quality certificate or samples must be included with the delivery.

 

  • 6.2. Deeper Dive: Document Integration for Quality in Procurement

A key concept mentioned throughout the source documents, particularly in the context of the material master's QM view, is the linkage of documents to enforce quality requirements during procurement. Let's break this down further.

  • The Role of Technical Delivery Conditions (CTL)

The "Condition Technique de Livraison," or CTL, is a business process, not just a single field. It's the practice of formally communicating special quality and delivery requirements to your suppliers. In SAP, this is achieved by linking a Document Info Record (DIR) to the material master.

  • What is a Document Info Record (DIR)? A DIR is a master data object in SAP's Document Management System (DMS). It acts as a carrier for metadata about a document (like a PDF, Word file, or CAD drawing). The DIR has a unique number, a type (e.g., Q02 for a quality-related document), a description, and a status (e.g., Released). You can attach the actual file (e.g., a PDF of your quality specification) to the DIR.
  • How does it work in our process?
    1. Requirement: Your business decides that for a specific material (e.g., 922173), every delivery from a supplier must be accompanied by a certificate of analysis and a sample from the batch.
    2. Documentation: You formalize these requirements in a document. This document is your "Technical Delivery Condition."
    3. SAP Document Creation: You create a DIR of type Q02 in SAP (e.g., CTL03). You give it a description like "Certificate + Samples Required" and attach the formal document file to it.
    4. Material Master Linkage: In the material master's QM view (MM01/MM02), you set a QM Control Key (e.g., Z004) that mandates CTL. This forces the system to require a document link. You then link the DIR

CTL03 to the material.

    1. Procurement Execution: When a purchase order is created for this material, the system can automatically print the text from the DIR or even the entire attached document as part of the PO sent to the supplier. This ensures the supplier is legally and formally notified of the requirements.
    2. Goods Receipt: At the time of goods receipt, the quality process is triggered. The receiving personnel are aware that a certificate and samples should be present with the delivery, as prompted by the system setup.

This integrated document management process creates a closed-loop, auditable trail that ensures your quality requirements are clearly communicated and tracked from purchasing through to inspection.

  • Conclusion

This guide has walked you through the complete lifecycle of a material within the SAP S/4HANA ecosystem, from its initial setup to its eventual retirement. By integrating the core functionalities of Materials Management (MM) and Quality Management (QM), we have demonstrated how a seamless, end-to-end business process is executed.

You have learned how to:

  • Establish a solid foundation by creating and maintaining essential master data for suppliers, materials, and batches.
  • Execute a procurement process with integrated quality checks by creating inbound deliveries for quality-managed materials.
  • Perform the quality inspection cycle by recording results and making usage decisions to ensure materials meet your standards.
  • Manage the product lifecycle by correctly obsoleting materials using deletion flags, ensuring data cleanliness and system integrity.

By practicing the steps outlined in the how-to guides and completing the comprehensive test plan, you will build the confidence and competence to navigate these critical business processes effectively. Whether you are an end-user performing daily tasks, a key user overseeing the process, or a consultant configuring the system, you now have a cohesive roadmap to success in SAP S/4HANA.

entry.title: Is there a way to dynamically change the names and legends of measure items in SAC?
entry.content:
Hello Community,

Is there a way to dynamically change the names and legends of measure items in SAC?

For example, suppose you have a numerical item called measure and want to display that measure item as a line graph broken down by fiscal year.
You can display a legend on a line chart, but I want the legend to show the fiscal year, such as “measure(2020)” and “measure(2021)”.

I want to display the fiscal year in the parentheses. Is it possible to dynamically specify the fiscal year?
Dynamic means that when data for fiscal year 2025 is newly added, “measure(2025)” will be added without requiring any editing operations.

The image display uses a calculated measure to create a numerical value field named “measure(2020)”, but this method cannot be considered dynamic.

Thanks best regards.

entry.title: Handling of IT 0004 in PTP Employee Replication
entry.content:
Context: When attempting to include Infotype 0004 in Point-to-Point (PTP) Employee Replication, you may encounter the following error message:

  "Infotype 0004 is not supported or customzied in T77SFEC_C_SUP_IT" , 

This occurs because, by default, SAP only supports a predefined list of infotypes for standard employee replication to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll (ECP). This list can be retrieved from the method IF_HRSFEC_INFTY_FILTER~GET_SUPPORTED_INFTY of the class CL_HRSFEC_INFTY_FILTER.

As on today below info types are listed in above method.

By default, only 31 standard infotypes are supported, and IT0004 is not among them.

To enable replication of Infotype 0004 (Challenges), an entry must be added to the configuration table T77SFEC_C_SUP_IT.

This table defines all customer-supported infotypes for replication from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC) to Employee Central Payroll (ECP).

To include IT0004 in the replication process, use transaction SM30 to manually add it to T77SFEC_C_SUP_IT. This step ensures that the system recognizes IT0004 as a valid infotype for replication.

In our case, the entry for IT0004 should be configured as shown below.

Additionally, to enable data replication for Infotype 0004, it is necessary to implement the BAdI HRSFEC_B_CE_CHANGE_IT0004 to map relevant data from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central to the corresponding fields in IT0004.

Below is a sample implementation snippet:

 

 

DATA: ls_p0004 TYPE p0004.
FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs_personal_information> TYPE pad_sfec_ce_personal_info,
               <fs_personal_information_cntr> TYPE pad_sfec_ce_personal_i_country.

DATA: lt_values TYPE pad_sfec_ce_fld_value_list_tab,
      ls_values TYPE pad_sfec_ce_field_value.

REFRESH ct_infty_0004.

LOOP AT is_person-personal_information ASSIGNING <fs_personal_information>
  WHERE start_date >= iv_full_transmission_start_dat.

  CLEAR: ls_p0004, lt_values.
  ls_p0004-pernr = iv_personnel_number.
  ls_p0004-infty = '0004'.
  ls_p0004-begda = <fs_personal_information>-start_date.
  ls_p0004-endda = <fs_personal_information>-end_date.

  LOOP AT <fs_personal_information>-personal_info_per_country ASSIGNING <fs_personal_information_cntr>
    WHERE country = 'DEU'.

    CLEAR: lt_values.

    ls_p0004-sbgru = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericstring2.
    ls_p0004-sbpro = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericnumber4-long_value.
    ls_p0004-sbfak = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericnumber5-long_value.
    ls_p0004-nachw = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericstring5.
    ls_p0004-dnstl = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericstring6.
    ls_p0004-dsitz = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericstring7.
    ls_p0004-sbgsz = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericstring8.
    ls_p0004-sbadt = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericdate1.

    lt_values = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-_value_list.
    LOOP AT lt_values INTO ls_values WHERE element_name EQ 'custom_date1'.
      ls_p0004-sbaud = ls_values-element_value.
    ENDLOOP.

    ls_p0004-wegdt = <fs_personal_information_cntr>-genericdate2.

    IF ls_p0004-sbgru IS NOT INITIAL.
      APPEND ls_p0004 TO ct_infty_0004.
    ENDIF.

  ENDLOOP.
ENDLOOP.

 

With these configurations in place, Infotype 0004 can now be successfully replicated as part of the employee data flow from SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central to Employee Central Payroll.

We hope this article has been helpful in guiding your implementation. 😊

entry.title: MD01N Behavior: Issuing Storage Location Not Set in Stock Transport Requisitions
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are currently using transaction code MD01N for MRP execution. During this process, the system generates Stock Transport Requisitions without populating the Issuing Storage Location.

Details:

  • We have assigned the Production Storage Location (MARC-LGPRO) in the MRP2 view of the material master.

However, our business requirement is to have the issuing storage location automatically set during the MD01N MRP run.

System Information:

Manohar

entry.title: Re: How to Handle Cross-Global Account Subscriptions and Customer-Managed HANA in CAP SaaS?
entry.content: as

entry.title: Re: How to Handle Cross-Global Account Subscriptions and...
entry.content:
Thanks a lot for your detailed insights — very helpful to get both the technical and organizational perspective.

On cross-global account subscriptions, I understand that while the OSB/service broker layer would technically allow it within the same region, the current limitation is more on SAP’s side regarding how subscriptions are exposed across global accounts. I’ll definitely keep an eye on the influence request you shared and raise this topic with our SAP contact as well.

On BYO HANA, it makes sense that while theoretically possible, it doesn’t align with how CAP and MTX are designed to manage lifecycle, provisioning, and schema isolation. For customers with stronger isolation needs, this probably points more toward a dedicated deployment model rather than true SaaS multitenancy.

Also, I’ve noticed that customers running S/4HANA on-premise or S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition typically have higher data privacy and control requirements, so they’re often not the “perfect” target for a multi-tenant SaaS solution. In those cases, a dedicated or single-tenant deployment model might be a more realistic option, whereas SaaS multitenancy seems to resonate better with customers already used to public cloud solutions.

Appreciate your feedback — it really helps to frame these discussions with customers and set the right expectations about what’s possible today versus what may evolve in the future.

Best regards,
Moudhaffer,

entry.title: Simplifying Maintenance Notification lifecycle with next gen app Manage Maintenance Notifications
entry.content:
Introducing a simplified and modernized app, "Manage Maintenance Notifications" (F5777), to process maintenance notifications by different personas via a single app. It is a one-stop shop for managing all aspects of notification.

This app offers the following -

  1. Creation of notification along with minor work and emergency work.
  2. Update of notification to modify or add the missing details.
  3. Actions such as Accept, Reject, Request for Information, Submit for Approval, and Complete notification are available based upon authorization.
  4. Order creation or assignment of an order to a notification can be carried out.
  5. Malfunction data can be added for notification.
  6. Determination of output items for notification.
  7. Handling of attachments for a notification.
  8. Task list assignment to notification and exploding of the task list to operations when an order is created.
  9. Define field control by marking certain fields as read-only or mandatory during create or change mode using BAdI ‘EAM_MAINTNOTIF_FIELD_CONTROL’.

Manage Maintenance Notifications app tailored for every Role-
Manage Maintenance Notifications app enables all the users involved with maintenance notification processing to carry out their tasks. The app is tailored for different roles-

  • Maintenance Supervisors (Catalog: SAP_EAM_BC_MN_MNG_PC): Create, Edit, Accept, Reject, Review, or Request additional information on notification.
  • Employees (Catalog: SAP_EAM_BC_MN_MNG_EMP_PC): Create and edit notifications in response to a supervisor's request for more information.
  • Users with an additional catalog for Order-related operations, like SAP_EAM_BC_MP_ORD_MNG_PC, will be allowed to create or assign an order after the notification is accepted.

Note: The respective catalogs are already added to the standard role templates for Maintenance Supervisor ‘SAP_BR_MAINT_SUPERVISOR’ and Maintenance Employee ‘SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE_MAINTENANCE’.

Some of the Key Features-

1. List of all maintenance notifications in one app-
The business user will only be able to process Reactive Maintenance (Y1) and Proactive Maintenance (Y2) notification types, but can display all types of maintenance notifications.
All the maintenance notifications with different phases are listed here.



Note: If the business user has a specific requirement for processing maintenance notifications with selected subphases, then a variant can be created with specific filter values using Variant management.



Similarly based on business user requirements, specifications can be saved as an App Tile, which provides quick and easy access for the user.

2. Creation of Notification, Minor Work, and Emergency Work-
The business user can create a maintenance notification for Reactive Maintenance (Y1) via F5777. The UI is adapted to show only the relevant sections during creation, such as Notification Scope and Attachments. After creation, the editing is disabled for maintenance notification by the Maintenance Employee.
The maintenance notification is created with the Submitted subphase and sent for Screening to the Maintenance Screener/Maintenance Supervisor. Once submitted, other sections will be visible for the maintenance notification.

Further enhancements/detailing on this maintenance notification can be performed by the Maintenance Supervisor during the screening phase.
The maintenance notification is accepted or rejected by the Maintenance Supervisor for processing.
The maintenance notification can be sent back to the reporter in case the Maintenance Supervisor needs more details via Action Required. This maintenance notification can be updated by either the person responsible or the reporter.

Note: Maintenance Supervisor can perform actions Accept, Reject, Action Required on multiple notifications from the List page.



2.1 Creation of Minor Work- The minor work offers the user to enter malfunction details during create mode. The Minor work is created for smaller tasks that are created after the job is done, hence the status is already in process (Accepted).


The Processing Context of the created maintenance notification will be set to Minor Work (02). The user can even append malfunction data by editing the maintenance notification later, and it can be completed once work is finished.

For Minor Work, Create Order and Assign Order actions are disabled as the nature of the work is small and has no cost or time recording requirement.


2.2 Creation of Emergency Work- The emergency work enables the user to create a maintenance notification, bypassing the screening phase. The Processing Context of the created maintenance notification will be set to Emergency Work (01).  
The app expects the business user to enter a few more fields(mandatory) as compared to other maintenance notifications.



On creating Emergency work, a downstream process will be triggered to approve notification, create order, approve order, and release order for execution. The created order will already be moved to the execution phase. The order information will be automatically updated in the header section of the emergency work. If the user needs to enhance the order details, then the user can navigate to Change Maintenance Order using the quick view.

 
Note: In case of any failure during emergency order creation/processing, the errors can be checked in the Application Logs (available on the List report page of the Manage Maintenance Notifications app). Once the issues are rectified, order creation can be retriggered by the ‘Create Order’ action for the respective maintenance notification.

 

3. Editing of Maintenance Notification-
The app offers updating notification types of Reactive Maintenance (Y1) and Proactive Maintenance (Y2). The editing is enabled at all the phases except when the maintenance notification is rejected, completed by the Maintenance Supervisor.

Note: Maintenance Employee can only edit the maintenance notification for which employee is responsible (either he/she is the creator or the person responsible) when it is in the Action required subphase.


4. Various actions can be performed-
The Maintenance Supervisor can Accept to approve the maintenance notification for further processing or Reject the maintenance notification.
Action Required is used by the Maintenance Supervisor to ask for any missing information in the maintenance notification. The responsible users (creator/person responsible/maintenance supervisor) can resubmit the maintenance notification via the Submit action after providing the required information.



Complete is to finish the notification processing and reach its final status.
Copy enables the user to copy the maintenance notification fields to a new maintenance notification, which will be created with the Screening phase.


5. Order creation and assignment to maintenance notification-
Once a Maintenance Notification is accepted, the Create Order and Assign Order actions are enabled if the Maintenance Order relevant business catalog with appropriate authorizations (such as ‘SAP_EAM_BC_MP_ORD_MNG_PC’) is assigned to the user. The business user can either create an order or assign an existing order to the maintenance notification.

Note: Order-related actions will be enabled if the business user has required authorization coming from any catalog with edit Maintenance Order relevant authorizations.

 

6. Adding Malfunction Details for maintenance notification-
The user can add, edit, and delete malfunction data for a maintenance notification along with causes and activities.


7. Handling of Attachments-
Business users can upload, download, delete, rename attachments, and add URL for the maintenance notification.
By default, 2 standard document types are supported- Images of Damage (YP1) and Manuals (YP2).



The business user’s role can be configured to carry out operations for a custom document type using the catalog ‘SAP_PLM_BC_DIR_CUSTOM_PC’.
For more information, see Harmonized Document Management.


8. Field control support via BAdI ‘EAM_MAINTNOTIF_FIELD_CONTROL’-
This BAdI is designed to control field behaviour in the Manage Maintenance Notifications app (F5777). It enables users to manage field properties, such as making them read-only or mandatory, during the creation or updating of notifications. It also allows setting conditions based on other fields to control behaviour.
For example, if custom logic is written such that the ‘Effect’ field is mandatory during Create mode, then the user will see this field marked mandatory while creating the notification.

Note: This BAdI allows defining field control on the following standard fields- Technical Object, Priority, Final Due Date, Effect, Failure Mode, and Required Start.
Other standard fields and custom fields can be controlled, but with limitations.

 

9. Printing or Output Management-
By default, SAP provides the 3 output forms for Notification- Breakdown report, Activity Report, and Notification Overview. ‘Determine Output Items’ action enables the user to create these forms in preparation status and send them for output or printing.

 

Thanks for reading this blog post.  Please share your thoughts in the comments. Stay tuned!

You can find a collection of blogs on SAP S/4HANA Asset Management Cloud release blogs here: The Link Collection for Asset Management

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here’s the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: “learn a test framework and run automated scripts,” we can say: “here are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.”

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a “Black Friday” scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure – run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure – fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn’t care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn’t about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It’s about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It’s the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

More information: 

Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
Int4 Suite — your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite
Agentic Testing and Simulation with Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph
